title: Catalans defy separatist advertisement ban
description:
(28 Sep 2017) People in the Spanish autonomous region of Catalonia continue to defy the central government's prohibition of pro-independence referendum advertising in the streets, ahead of the vote on Sunday 1 October.
Gracia neighbourhood, right in the middle of the city of Barcelona, has historically been a stronghold of separatism.
Every night since 20 September, a group of youngsters, led by academic and political science investigator Jordi Graupera, print posters advertising the referendum.
The ads are replicas of the ones designed by the Catalan regional government and were later deemed illegal by Madrid’s judicial authorities.
Thousands of people supporting the contested referendum to split Catalonia from Spain took to Barcelona’s streets last week, amid an intensifying government crackdown on the independence vote.
Spanish authorities arrested a dozen regional officials and seized over a million ballot papers and banners advertising the referendum.
Only hours after the detentions, websites containing replicas of the banners and asking sympathisers to print them mushroomed the internet.
Jordi Graupera created the website "empaperem.cat" (Catalan for "let’s glue those ads"), which was later closed by the Spanish police force, the Guardia Civil.
Graupera currently lives in the United States, where he teaches and investigates political science at Princeton University.
He says there are dozens of other citizens' groups like his doing the same throughout Catalonia.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/74f7c1a04ebd57771f726dc44fccfd74 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
